description: Sum of nonprime divisors of n.
comments: Obviously a(n) < sigma(n) for all n > 1, where sigma(n) is the sum of divisors function (A000203). It thus follows that a(n) = 1 when n = 1 or n is prime. - _Alonso del Arte_, Mar 16 2013
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..1000
Y. Puri and T. Ward, Arithmetic and growth of periodic orbits, J. Integer Seqs., Vol. 4 (2001), #01.2.1.
formula: Equals A051731 * A037282. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 06 2007a(n) = A023891(n) + 1 (sum of composite divisors of n + 1). [_Alonso del Arte_, Oct 01 2008]a(n) = A000203(n) - A008472(n). - _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 14 2011a(n) = Sum (a027750(n,k)*(1-A010051(a027750(n,k))): k=1..A000005(n)). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 12 2014
example: a(8) = 13 because the divisors of 8 are 1, 2, 4, 8, and without the 2 they add up to 13.a(9) = 10 because the divisors of 9 are 1, 3, 9, and without the 3 they add up to 10.
mathematica: Array[ Plus @@ (Select[ Divisors[ # ], (!PrimeQ[ # ])& ])&, 75 ]Table[DivisorSum[n, # &, Not[PrimeQ[#]] &], {n, 75}] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Mar 16 2013 *)
prog: (PARI) a(n)=if(n<1, 0, sumdiv(n,d, !isprime(d)*d)) /* _Michael Somos_, Jun 08 2005 */(Haskell)a023890 n = sum $ zipWith (*) divs $ map ((1 -) . a010051) divs            where divs = a027750_row n-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 12 2014
